newsitem.title: GERMANY: German DAX pushes ahead as Wall St gains early on.
newsitem.headline: German DAX pushes ahead as Wall St gains early on.

text.p: German shares finished firmly ahead on Thursday, with a strong showing by U.S. stocks and the dollar pushing the DAX index through the 3,000 point level and allowing the gains to be extended in late German trade.

The 30-share DAX index ended up 18.12 points at 3,017.32 points, with the IBIS DAX index of electronic trade later closing 20.63 points, or 0.69 percent, ahead at 3,018.58 as U.S. stocks started a new session ahead.
Star performer on the German DAX was Allianz AG after investment house Goldman Sachs raised its rating on the German insurer.
The upgrade sparked a rally in Allianz that saw its shares rise some five percent to a new record high at 3,088 marks, before its shares eased in post-bourse trade to 3,062.50.

The broader market had already advanced on the back of an overnight rally on Wall Street and the dollar trading steady at 1.64 marks in European dealings on Thursday, a level that it held onto throughout the day.

Among other shares, carmaker BMW AG surged to 1,067 marks before paring gains to end bourse trade up 22.50 marks at 1,052.50 marks after it said 1996 output rose four percent to 1.14 million units and it expected stable sales in 1997.

But shares in chemical and drugs group Bayer AG ended down 96 pfennigs at 61.34 marks after a U.S. judge on Wednesday ordered Bayer's U.S. unit to pay a $50 million fine for an international conspiracy to fix prices and allocate prices for citric acid.

Traders said the fine would have little, if any, impact on Bayer's financial outlook and said the share's weak performance was in part due to general selling pressure on German drug and chemical shares.
